tallest spire will get a glimpse of them.The project has been under development since  when Salisbury Community Energy approached the cathedral about a possible installation.The  are collectively owned by small, local and ethical investors who want to encourage more renewable energy generation.Thomas Burnett, a director of the not-for-profit Salisbury Community Energy, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have been able to work with our partners to make this installation happen.ldquoIt was always a very important site for Salisbury Community Energy as it sends a strong message.ldquoWe hope title: make-diy-face-mask-using-just-t-shirt-hair-bobbles
story: FACE coverings are to become mandatory across all shops in Scotland as of tomorrow.Following the move to make the coverings compulsory on public transport, the First Minister argued that"as we all start to interact more, it is vital that we take all reasonable steps to reduce risk."And we know that these coveringscan help reduce the risk of transmission indoors."To help people along with the process, the Scottish Government have released a handy video on how to make your own face mask - using just a hair bobble or rubber band and a T-shirt.Watch how to make your own DIY mask below:From Friday  July, you will be required by law to wear a face covering when you go into a shop. Face coverings are already mandatory on all public transport.Some exemptions apply, which you can read about at https:t.co uCivwyYlLearn how to make your own ## pic yGmXylLrmdash Scottish GovernmentJuly , How will it be enforced The First Minister said the rules will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport.She said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only at a last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:Police officers first responders in an emergencyStaff separate by a physical barrier ndash including bus drivers behind a screenAnyone with ahealthcondition where a mask would cause dficulty, including asthmaYou need to take medicationTo speak with someone who lip readsWhen asked to remove it by a relevant authority, e.g. Police officer.But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced From tomorrow,the two-metre social distancing rule can be reduced in the hospitality and retail sectors and on public transport at that time.Pubs, restaurants and shops will be allowed to adhere to a one-metre rule instead, with mitigation measures in place.But the general rule in law will be that businesses must take reasonable measures to ensure two-metre distancing is maintained, she said.

title: uk-australian-data-regulators-investigate-clearview-ai
story: Data regulators in the UK and Australia have announced a joint investigation into practices of facial recognition app Clearview AI.The UK Information Commissionerrsquos Officeand the Office of the Australian Information Commissionersaid they are looking into the firmrsquos use of data ldquoscraped from the internet.Clearview AI uses its facial recognition software to help law enforcement match photos of unknown people to other images online by using the companyrsquos database of photos which have been taken from publicly accessible social media s, including Facebook, and other websites.We have opened a joint investigation into Clearview AI Inc with the @OAICgov. The investigation focuses on Clearviewrsquos use of lsquoscrapedrsquo data and biometrics of iniduals. Joint statement here: https:t.co XTwbBUAPOepic iLEmBNQqZmdash ICOJuly , The controversial system has raised questions about privacy and consent to data gathering but has been used by a number of law enforcement agencies in the US.A report by Buzzfeed earlier this year also claimed that a number of UK law enforcement agencies had registered with Clearview, including the politan Police and the National Crime Agency as well as other regional police forces.At the time, the Met denied it had used Clearviewrsquos services.Clearviewrsquos founder, Hoan Ton-That, has previously described the app as ldquoa search engine for publicly available images, but the company says it is not a tool available to the public.ldquoThe Office of the Australian Information Commissionerand the UKrsquos Information Commissionerrsquos Officehave opened a joint investigation into the personal information handling practices of Clearview AI Inc, focusing on the companyrsquos use of lsquoscrapedrsquo data and biometrics of iniduals, the regulators said in a statement.ldquoThe investigation highlights the importance of enforcement co-operation in protecting the personal information of Australian and UK citizens in a globalised data environment.Clearview has not yet commented on the launch of the investigation..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: UK and Australian data regulators to investigate Clearview AI

title: musselburgh-marlins-become-first-east-lothian-club-achieve-top-swim-benchmark
story: Already proud holders of a SwiMark certicate, received in , they have now been awarded SwiMark Plus in Scottish Swimmingrsquos accreditation scheme which provides a nationally recognised standard for clubs and swim schools.Head coach Danny Kirkham said: ldquoMusselburgh Amateur Swimming Clubis delighted to have been awarded Scottish Swimmingrsquos highest accreditation, SwiMark Plus.ldquoThis means that Scottish Swimming recognises MASC as a quality programme which is swimmer centred and strives to ensure we provide the best environment possible for our swimmers to reach their full potential.ldquoThis award shows MASC are leading the way in setting new standards for swimming in the community. Through the work undertaken, a development plan which spans the whole club will ensure we keep progressing and moving forward to ensure MASC remains strong and sustainable long into the future.The club has come a long way since its origins in , when swimmers used to hone their skills in the local harbour. The pool at Loretto School was used over the years before the club moved to Musselburgh Sports Centre after it opened in .A year ago, MASCrsquos management committee and coaches held a planning meeting with Scottish Swimming to establish the steps required to be completed in order to achieve SwiMark Plus.A small voluntary project group embarked on reviewing, revising and signing off the extensive SwiMark criteria before engaging in consultative activities across the club, implementing revised and new policies and procedures, analysing data and producing a four year development and action plan.Club president and project manager Gill Downie said: ldquoMany thanks to the small project team heavily involved in delivering this huge feat through endless hours of blood, sweat and tears. It really is a remarkable achievement during the transitional year following chairman Jack Calderrsquos death ndash illustrating MASCrsquos resilience, drive and passion to be recognised as a trusted leader within aquatics sport by offering exceptional all-encompassing swimming development programmes, coaching education tuition and volunteer training within the community. In addition, effective club management and robust financial review systems will ensure MASC is a viable family-friendly resource within East Lothian well into the future.Alan Reed, Scottish Swimmingrsquos regional swimming development manger , added: ldquoWith the committee and other members working hard to gain this award, they have shown that they are a really strong and sustainable club.ldquoA crucial part of the accreditation is the formation of a development plan ndash this ensures that the club is making consistent progress and looks towards the future.ldquoThe club has excellent structures that have been put in place through the process and this has been demonstrated by all the engagement and activity the club has continued through this recent period of change. It has been a pleasure working with the club and helping support them to gain their SwiMark Plus accreditation.The top benchmark is also held by East Lothian Swim Team which provides a performance training environment for countyrsquos top talent. The best swimmers from Musselburgh, Tranent and Haddington Amateur Swimming Clubs train together as a single composite team to achieve success at East District, Scottish National, British and International levels.

title: preston-athletic-footballers-getting-bikes-good-causes
story: Members of Prestonpans-based Preston Athleticrsquos squad are getting on their bikes for a special fundraiser, which will see them visit the homes of  football teams in East Lothian, Edinburgh and Midlothian.Money raised will be split between the East of Scotland side and the NHS, as a thank you for the hard work of its staff.The cycle, had been due to take place last Saturday but was postponed to a still-to-be-confirmed new date, was the idea of team-mates Kai Austin and Nathan Stokes.Twenty-one-year-old Kai, who plays right back for the side, said: ldquoA lot of clubs have been making signings and we knew Preston were struggling even to just keep going.ldquoI have seen where someone has cycled or driven to the  league grounds [in the Scottish Premiership to League Two].ldquoWe thought maybe it would be a cool idea to do something like that at our level.ldquoWe came up with a challenge to entice people to want to donate and will us on.ldquoWe came up with visiting  grounds for  teams for the   season.The teammates plan to start at New Countess Park, home of Dunbar United.From there, it is on to Millfield , Foresters Parkand New Recreation Park .The cyclists will then head into Midlothian and tick off Kingrsquos Park , Newbattle Complex , New Victoria Park , Newbyres Park , New Dundas Park , Ferguson Parkand Penicuik Park .Then it is into the Capital for stops at Paties Road , Meggetland , Saughton Enclosure , Christie Gillies Park , Ainslie Park Stadium , St Marks Parkand finally Peffermill .Finally, the weary cyclists willto East Lothian and tick off Olivebankbefore reaching the finish line and familiar surroundings of The Pennypit .In total, the cycle, which is about  kilometres , is expected to take upwards of seven hours, with the players stopping for a photograph at each ground.The fundraiser is also the latest step on the road to recovery for midfielder Nathan.The -year-old missed the entire   season after a horror ankle injury in pre-season, which saw ligaments ripped off the bone.Now, he is keen to get back to fitness ahead of the new campaign kicking off.He said: ldquoI have still been going to watch matches and getting the changing room banter.ldquoWe are all in a group chat and a lot of the boys have been working on their fitness throughout lockdown.ldquoThey have been out running or cycling and a lot of the boys are keen to get back to it and we are all missing it, especially myself.ldquoI am hoping to be back for next season.ldquoIt has been a long hard battle to get back fit after surgery.ldquoIt has been three months since surgery and the doctor and physio said it would be three to six months before I am back playing.Nathan, who previously played for Musselburgh Windsor and Ormiston, has played at most of the grounds but will tick off visiting Haddington, Newtongrange Star, Arniston Rangers and Civil Service Strollers during the cycle.He was looking forward to the fundraiser and was pleased with the reaction from members of the public, with more than pound already donated.He said: ldquoMy mum is a carer, Irsquove got family and friends who work in the NHS, so it is a no brainer to be honest.ldquoMyself and Kai said we should half the money with the NHS. The work they are doing just now is remarkable.To support the club, go to www.justgiving crowdfunding prestonathletic

title: social-enterprise-heavy-sound-finds-new-home-hub
story: The organisation, which champions community projects supporting the disadvantaged and young people, is moving into The Cockenzie Hub, formerly Cockenzie Business Centre, after taking on a three-year lease.The move will allow Heavy Sound, previously based in Tranent, to continue its work, with recent projects including refitting a bus with the help of prisoners at HMP Edinburgh, in Saughton, to create a mobile community centre.Heavy Sound uses rap, hip-hop, art and sports to work with young people from a iety of backgrounds.Jordan Butler, CEO of the organisation, said: ldquoFor the last five years we have been based in Tranent and, as a growing organisation, have found it dficult to find the right space in East Lothian to make a longer-term move.ldquoThe Cockenzie Hub is perfect for us we will be able to provide a full range of services as well as develop new programmes which will service Cockenzie and the wider community.The business hub was bought by Allied Surveyors Scotland on behalf of East Lothian-based Moscar LLP last October.Iain Mercer, of Allied Surveyors, welcomed the arrival of Heavy Sound to the hub.He said: ldquoThis underlines the demand for accommodation from local companies seeking affordable business space.

title: visitors-given-green-light-return-eskgreen
story: The facility ndash on Shorthope Street near the River Esk ndash closed in mid-March and escaped the deadly virus. Run by East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership , the  residents, aged between  and , have been keeping ldquoin good heart during the lockdown.An ELHSCP spokesperson confirmed: ldquoNo one has contracted Covid- at Eskgreen.Now, in line with Scottish Governmentguidance, the residents are looking forward to meeting visitors in outdoor areas only on Wednesdays and Saturdays, -.am and -pm, and Sundays, -pm and -.pm.At the moment, visits are restricted to one lsquokey visitorrsquo and will be held in outdoor areas.Clair Anderson, manager, said: ldquoItrsquos been hard because obviously people are missing their families and friends, but we all know why it has to be this way and we decided to make the best we could of it.ELHSCP introduced very restricted visiting to its four care homes, including Eskgreen, in mid-March, swtly followed by no visiting from March .Clair said: ldquoWe had to act very quickly but I think residents and families understood why and were behind us.ldquoWe managed to get our hands on Kindles and iPads very quickly and helped residents to Skype and FaceTime family and friends. This has really helped to keep people in touch regularly and relieve familiesrsquo anxieties.ldquoWe have a brilliant team spirit in Eskgreen. Relatives and staff have pulled together throughout the outbreak and have concentrated on trying to get as much out of le as possible, even though we were all living through a very challenging time.ldquoWe have kept ourselves really busy and really positive. I think the key to it is trying to get as much fun out of le as you can. So, we have had skittles evenings, birthday parties, Easter celebrations and we pulled out all the stops for VE Day ndash we even had a piper playing in the grounds.ldquoWersquove also had wonderful support from community groups, who have sent gts for us ndash residents and staff! Itrsquos brilliant to have such tangible proof that everyone is thinking of us.ldquoWersquove focused on being active and creative ndash we sing, we dance, we even made a video ndash Somewhere Over the Rainbow ndash which went viral locally."You can see it at bit.ly CZizla and it features residents singing The Wizard of Oz classic and is guaranteed to bring a tear to the eye.ldquoItrsquos also about helping people feel good about themselves so wersquove done a lot of pampering sessions ndash we all have lovely hair and great nails.ldquoWersquove had great help from ELHSCPrsquos care home team too. Theyrsquore a nurse-led team that have been working in care homes across East Lothian for the last four years.ldquoIn addition to their routine work of looking after the clinical needs of residents, like medication and wound care, they also really stepped up to help us during Covid.ldquoThey made sure that all the care homes they work with were on top of the guidance, which was being updated all the time, had access to all the PPE they needed and knew how and when to use it.ldquoI think all care homes in East Lothian, ELHSCP and private, have been doing their very best to keep people cheerful and safe.ldquoAt Eskgreen, I would have to say that we have great support from families, a great staff team and, most of all, great residents. Thatrsquos the secret of our success.Irene Tait, chair of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, said: ldquoWe were delighted and heartened at the way the management and staff of Eskgreen have coped with the coronavirus.ldquoThrough their diligence and great care, they have kept the residents and staff safe from contracting the virus.ldquoWe are all aware of the huge debt of thanks we owe to everyone working in our health and care sector however, itrsquos especially nice to hear good news in our own town and we can be very proud of them.ldquoI would also like to thank everyone who has rallied round to help neighbours, family and strangers at this time ndash it all matters.

title: historic-trees-connection-business-recognised
story: Nine lime trees are planted on the western side of the River Tyne near St Maryrsquos Parish Church, with the oldest of the trees thought to date back more than a century.Haddington and District Amenity Society, which folded last October, is behind the plans for the plaque, which would be put in place on the wall along the eastern edge of Lady Kittyrsquos Garden, off The Sands.Andrew Robinson, the founding and final chairman of the group, told the Courier: ldquoWe had been considering for some time putting up a plaque close to the nine lime trees in the Ball Alley, Haddington.ldquoThe trees are there to mark the presence in the town of the nine trading incorporations from medieval times through to the th century.ldquoThe nine trades represented are the baxters, the hammermen, the masons, the wrights, the fleshers, the cordiners, the skinners, the tailors and the wabsters.ldquoThe money for the plaque was set aside at the time the society disbanded in October , and we very much look forward to putting it in place once we have obtained the necessary planning and listed building consents.ldquoAnother of our lsquolast actsrsquo was the installation of a plaque in memory of Frank Tindall on the west-facing gable of  Bridge Street, just across the bridge from the Ball Alley.Plans for the plaque are with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.The plaque, which will be made of a composite material with a printed image, would measure  centimetres in width and nearly  centimetres in height.Documents included within the planning application highlight the wording of the proposed plaque, which needs planning permission as it is on a listed building.It reads: ldquoThis row of nine lime trees is said to represent the nine trade guilds of Haddington.ldquoNo one knows who planted the original nine, but the oldest of the current trees dates from about .ldquoThe line of trees marks the old road between the High Street and St Maryrsquos Kirk and offers an important reminder of the trades in existence before .ldquoTrade guilds of Haddington dating from the Middle Ages are represented on this shield: Top row: masons , wrights , wabsters .ldquoMiddle row: hammermen , skinners , cordiners .ldquoBottom row: baxters , fleshers , tailors .

title: pharmacy-owner-retiring-four-decades
story: As he is currently shielding due to the Covid- pandemic, he was sad not to be able to say a fond farewell to his many customers.Eskside Pharmacy has been sold to a new owner and will continue to provide pharmaceutical care for local people.Mr Chetty said: ldquoItrsquos been an immense pleasure to have served the people of Musselburgh and surrounding areas for the last  years. The loyalty and support of the community has been humbling and greatly appreciated.ldquoIrsquom also grateful for the strong working relationships Irsquove had with the surgeries and GPs.ldquoIrsquove been very fortunate to have had such fantastic, hard-working and cheerful staff through all the years and I canrsquot thank them enough for all they have done.ldquoThe current circumstances of Covid- have meant that I havenrsquot been able to say farewells to people in person, which is of great regret. My thoughts will always be with you all and I will still be a regular face up and down High Street.ldquoIrsquom in no doubt the new owners will continue high standards of pharmaceutical care.Mr Chetty, , started at Eskside Pharmacy on High Street in , initially as the manager, before buying the business in .Originally from South Africa, he came to Scotland to study in Edinburgh in the s ndash when apartheid wouldnrsquot allow him to study for the profession in South Africa.As manager of the local pharmacy, he enjoyed the community spirit in Musselburgh and jumped at the chance of establishing and developing the pharmacy.The overriding memory he will take with him is the ldquopositive rapport he has developed with the patients and the people of Musselburgh. He said serving the health and wellbeing of the community had been his number one priority and he always felt that was appreciated by his customers and wider community.He recalled one of his most special memories, when his daughter was in hospital with meningitis and he found out that every church in Musselburgh had said a prayer for her recovery.Just a few months ago, when he was piercing the ears of a girl at the shop, her grandmother told him he had pierced her ears too as well as her daughterrsquos ears, making this the third generation of the same family he had served.He joked that he decided that might be his cue to retire.Mr Chetty, who lives in Longniddry, said Musselburgh had always had a ldquothriving High Street, but it had been challenging to maintain a wide range of businesses to serve the community. He hoped High Street would always remain at the heart of the community.Mr Chetty, who has three children and four grandchildren, one of whom was born just two weeks ago, sadly lost his we Moira two years ago. He said he was ldquovery grateful for the support of the community during her illness and when she passed away.In his retirement, he is looking forward to playing golf, tending his garden and travelling, as well as spending time with his grandchildren. He is also hoping to spend time with family in South Africa.

title: column-reassuring-statistics---time-focus-economy
story: Now that we have lessened the risk to health from Covid- for the time being, it is time to start focusing on supporting the recovery of the economy.We have to consider the implications there will be for employees following the end of the furlough scheme, and ensure that both iniduals and employers have the necessary support at this time.I want to ensure that all businesses receive the help that they are entitled to and have the best possible opportunity to overcome this period of crisis.Irsquom always happy to hear from local business owners, whether that be to get an update on the work they are doing or to discuss what I can do to ensure they are being supported.I would encourage local business owners to get in touch to discuss any dficulties or concerns that they might have in this unpredictable period.I canrsquot promise miracles but I will certainly do all that I can to help.It is great to see that retail premises will begin to re-open and I know that this will be hugely beneficial to many small and local businesses across the constituency.Whilst we all enjoy having access to some of our local shops again, I would like to remind everyone to do this in a responsible way by maintaining social distancing, wearing a face covering and following the hygiene advice in place.I encourage you all to make use of the many local shops and businesses that we are lucky enough to have in East Lothian and to do so in a responsible manner that respects any rules shop owners may have put in place to keep us all safe.I would also like to welcome theof horse racing behind closed doors, as Musselburgh Racecourse begins its flat season this week.I have been in regular contact with those from the racecourse throughout the Covid- crisis and I am pleased that they will begin to recover from this unprecedented period of closure.

title: column-must-act-now-prevent-lost-generation
story: Latest official statistics show that the level of --year-olds claiming unemployment benefits has almost doubled between February and May, rising to . per cent.A report from independent economic thinktank the Fraser of Allander Institute said the country was now in its deepest recession in living memory, with a minimum of  months before the economy recovers to pre-pandemic levels.It is deeply worrying that Scotlandrsquos working population is already suffering so much at the very start of this economic crisis.The recently published Higgins economic recovery report reiterated the importance of a Jobs Guarantee Scheme, warning that workers under the age of  are two and half times more likely than those aged  and older to work in sectors that have been shut down in response to Covid-.Scottish Labour has been calling for such a scheme since the start of the crisis.We want the Scottish Government to work with employers and trade unions to develop a jobs guarantee scheme paying at least the living wage and offering a secure job or training place to any worker who has been unemployed for the long term.Young people have been especially hit by the lockdown of the economy, and as we see a fragile recovery we expect more people on furlough will face unemployment.That is why we need to act fast to ensure Covid- does not result in theof mass unemployment and all the damage that does to the fabric of society.We urgently need a plan for the economy and jobs and an industrial strategy with manufacturing at its heart.If we fail to act now we face losing a whole generation to the blight of unemployment.This is not just a question of economics, it is a question of doing the right thing.

title: crossing-point-things-keep-awake-night
story: As I lay there all I could hear was, to borrow the title of a famous song, the lsquoSound of Silencersquo.Not a car drove past. Not even the number  night bus that trundles through Port Seton on an hourly basis.Was it the silence that was keeping me awake  Or was it the fact that, by this time, my mind was racing ahead to the things that I had to do the next day In these recent months, one of the most common things to hear people say is that their sleeping pattern isnrsquot what it once was.I even Googled it and came across an article from a popular news website in which those interviewed recounted how the events of recent months had affected their ability to sleep.It seems that much of this has been caused by the changes to our daily routine.As we have been spending more time at home than usual, wersquore not expending the same energy as we do when times are more lsquonormalrsquo.Even sunny days, when we would normally go out and soak up the sun, are often spent inside the coolness of our homes.And,we are honest, we probably need to add into the mix a certain measure of anxiety.It is not easy to hear even the improving facts and figures that are circulated each day, nor to be reminded that, whilst things might be looking up, such a situation relies on our continued responsible behaviour.As I lay awake, which included thinking about what I would put into this column that you are now reading, I was reminded of the Psalmist in the Old Testament who confesses that sometimes he too lies awake at night, his mind buzzing around from here to there.So, what does he do when he cannot sleep Psalm  and verse : ldquoOn my bed I remember you I think of you through the watches of the night.He turns his attention to God. Something worth considering as we too doze on and off in the wee small hours.

title: tims-tales-st-andrews-old-kirk
story: The fallen-down walls and tall standing central gable give it a very picturesque quality, perfectly situated just beyond the edge of the golf course.I may be wrong, but I suspect it is not really a place many people purposely go to visit. As ruins go, therersquos not a huge amount to explore no cramped spiral staircase to squeeze up, or dank cellars to investigate.But for me, such ruins have a dferent appeal. Not based so much on the physical exploration of what remains, but more an imaginative exploration of what we can no longer see.It has really ancient origins, dating back to the ninth century when the first Christian site seems to have been established here. That gives it over a thousand years of Christian connection, and I suspect it may have been a pre-Christian sacred site before that.The first kirk will have been wooden built, but the oldest surviving parts of the stone kirk we see today date from the late th century.On my most recent visit to the kirk, I stood in the nave and tried to imagine what Scotland was like in the s when parts of the walls around me were built. What a totally dferent world from ours, I thought, as I stood in the footsteps of those who stood on the same spot hundreds of years ago.On reflection, perhaps there were more similarities than we may imagine: pestilence, plague and epidemics, injustice and inequality, cruel rulers and pious preachers.There are some information boards with pictorial reconstructions that help us understand what we are looking at, but a ruin like this is the stuff of poetic imagination.Poets such as Shelley were inspired by ruins, and today they are popular visitor attractions all over the world.Compared to the scale of ruins such as the Acropolis or Pompeii, or even compared to nearby ruins such as Dirleton Castle, the old kirk of St Andrew may not impress. I donrsquot think it will ever be a popular tourist attraction.But thatrsquos why I enjoy visiting this place. Itrsquos a ruin with solitude, while ironically being very accessible and amidst a busy part of East Lothian.Over the years I have never personally met anyone  there visiting it. Many people know of it, of course, but because of its unassuming simplicity, I suspect few have got to know it.ldquoTherersquos not much to see, was an honest comment from a friend once. He was right on one level, but I think what we see depends how we look, and how we connect.For me anyway, the magic of this ruined kirk is not in what is visible but in the atmosphere of its story, and its unexpected tranquillity.Once, of course, it was very busy, for it was the place of worship for people from the edge of Aberlady Bay to the fringes of North Berwick, as well as from as far as four miles to the south. Every Sabbath there would have been processions of people from each direction, coming to meet and worship here together.Stand in the nave and you are at the centre of this ancient weekly migration. From here you will see a Norman arch, decorated with chevrons. Although the information board points out the craftsmanship is not of the finest quality, it makes me imagine some poorly paid, yet skilled, local stonemasons doing their best to beauty their kirk and it is certainly good enough.The arch was walled up many years ago, when the chancel became a burial place for the Yule family. So the decorated arch is now embedded in later stone, and looks like a fossil peeking out from a clf face.As I stood admiring it, I thought it had the atmosphere of a walled-up entrance into the past, in which figures from times gone by could emerge or perhaps I could walk through it to another age. Maybe Irsquove been watching too much Outlander .The kirk was used for worship for over  years, and even survived the Reformation. There is an amusing tale of the vicar from that time, which I shared in my first book. I thought of him as I stood in his church.It became a collegiate church in , so prayers were said here constantly by a group of priors to help the soul of the local laird to get into heaven. The prayers were paid for, of course, and one wondersthe laird got value for money.The kirk was finally abandoned around , apparently because of a petition from parishioners.One issue seems to have been the constant covering of sand blown over the kirk and kirkyard by endemic storms. What image does that conjure in our imagination  And what storms must they have been! But also, many people lived miles away from the kirk, as did the laird, and a new, more conveniently situated place of worship was wanted.I can understand this. Itrsquos a fair trek from, say, Dirleton to here, especially on an unpleasant, dark, cold winterrsquos morning. So a new replacement kirk was built at Dirleton, and St Andrewrsquos Kirk fell into disuse. Yet the kirkyard remained in use, and has many of its own tales to tell.I have never been a fan of crowded places, to be honest. Irsquove had my enjoyment of some favourite places ruined by being placed on a tourist lsquomust-seersquo list.I doubt the ruins of the old kirk of St Andrew in Gullane will ever be on a tourist lsquomust-seersquo list unless some celebrity gets married there, or itrsquos used as a movie location.It remains for me a wonderful place to visit, and I always spot small details that I missed on previous visits. My kids are fascinated by the stories told on the gravestones.As the lockdown eases, we are all understandably desperate to get out from our confinement and feel free once again to enjoy places. But then we often too readily build a new prison for ourselves by following the herd to overcrowded places where we are crammed into lsquomust-go-torsquo popular places.Maybe a gt from the lockdown is the discovery of those places nearby, less well known, but in their own way special and magical.For me, East Lothian is full of such small, less-well-known, special places, that will never be a on a lsquomust-seersquo list, but are all the more enjoyable for it. This old ruin is one of them for me.It is such places I look forward to visiting as the lockdown eases.

title: farewell-alfred-alf-tesoro
story: He died suddenly of a presumed heart attack at the age of , as he ed to his home in Eskside West after buying his daily newspaper on June .Due to current Covid- restrictions, a private service was conducted on Monday, June , at Inveresk Cemetery by Father Basil Clark, from Our Lady of Loretto Church on Newbigging, Musselburgh.The funeral cortegravege travelled along North High Street, passing his former cafe premises for the last time, to applause from members of the local community who lined the street to pay their respects.His niece Anita Cullinan said: ldquoOur family were truly touched by all who turned up to witness Alfrsquos last journey through Musselburgh ndash people who perhaps personally knew Alf or who had grown up during the years the shop was open.ldquoWersquod like to thank them for turning out and for the deeply respectful applause as the cortegravege passed by.Alf was born in the house above the shop on  North High Street on July , , the middle child of Edoardo Tesoro and Zelinda Costa Tesoro, whose other two children were Eolanda and Bert.Edoardo started the cafe known as A.Tesoro in , and his brother Emilio also started a Tesoro cafe across the bridge in Musselburgh around the same time. They married the Costa sisters, Zelinda and Carmen.Le was hard as Alfrsquos parents worked in the s through to the late s, with Zelinda looking after the children, maintaining a home and helping in the shop. They would have worked seven days a week, from dawn till dusk.Like most Italian immigrants of the time, they built the business from nothing to create a small ice cream factory behind the cafe.The ice cream was made by hand and boiled in small quantities each day in response to the demand. They didnrsquot have a pasteurising machine until after the Second World War, which then allowed larger quantities to be made and stored.Ice was delivered to the cafe each day and kept in a cool cabinet and the ice cream was then made using a secret family recipe, passing from father to son.The ice cream was then delivered by horse and cart to ious places around Portobello and Musselburgh and also distributed by bicycles with cool boxes in front to keep it fresh.They had young lads helping to distribute the ice cream and family members remember Alf saying that they also attended the Musselburgh Racecourse events and dance halls to expand the business.Alf started a car mechanicrsquos course on New Street, Musselburgh, before the war but hadnrsquot completed it before being called up to serve in the British Army as a private in the Argyll  Sutherland Highlanders Regiment.He served in both France and Germany, arriving in Normandy on June , , and spending the rest of the war in France, Holland and Germany.He ed to Musselburgh with the intention to finish his apprenticeship and learn how to drive but, as was so often the case with the eldest son of Italian families at the time, was asked by his father to run the business.His sister, Eolanda, had finished her secretarial studies after the war and met a young Italian called Ricardo Paganuzzi, who she married and who set up an ice cream business called Dinorsquos Cafe in Perth.His younger brother, Bert, went on to study law at the University of Edinburgh after he finished his national service.He married an Edinburgh girl called Catherine OrsquoDonnell, who studied to be a teacher.Alf therefore found himself the last of the siblings left in the business and stayed to continue work until his retirement ndash around  years.After he retired and, in the absence of successors to run the business, he sold up around  and continued to spend his remaining  or so years living very happily in his native Musselburgh.He travelled to the USA and to Canada but mainly spent his annual holidays with his nephew, Dino Paganuzzi, in Switzerland.He went on numerous trips back with Dino to where their family originated, Beverino, in the region of La Spezia in northern Italy, where relatives still live.He announced very shortly after ing from a family trip to Rome that his travelling days were now over, at the age of nearly .Alf was a member of the hiking club run by Our Lady of Loretto Catholic Church, where he seldom missed a Sunday Mass.He also spent many a Saturday at Easter Road in Edinburgh with his brother Bert, watching his beloved Hibs play football.Alf is survived by his nephew Dino Paganuzzi in Switzerland, niece Anita Cullinan, from Edinburgh, cousin Roland Toma, of the Cafe Continental in Gourock, cousin Elena Grippa in Rome, and their children.Many Musselburgh residents took to social media to pay tribute to Alf. Fiona Rutherford posted: ldquoLoved his cafe.Gillian Duffy said: ldquoAlways used to be the place to hang out at Alfiersquos when a teenager.Alan Fraser said: ldquoBrilliant recognition by the people of Musselburgh.Elaine Black added: ldquoHappy memories. The best ice cream.

title: stunning-winter-photograph-turned-impressive-jigsaw
story: The impressive picture, taken by Linda Clanahan, captured the hearts of Haddington residents.Community resilience volunteers have set up a lending library, which allows members of the public to borrow jigsaws, books, games and DVDs.To mark the launch of the lending library, a competition was held to find a suitable picture of the town which could be transformed into a jigsaw.More than  entries were submitted, with members of the resilience team picking out their top .Members of the public then selected Lindarsquos picture as their favourite, with nearly  votes cast.The Gourlaybank resident, who is yet to complete the jigsaw, was delighted to win.She said: ldquoI took the photograph such a long time ago.ldquoIt was in  and there were a couple of years around Christmas time when it was really snowy.ldquoI got quite a lot of good shots over those years and this was just one of my favourite ones.ldquoThe bridge itself is one of the most endearing features about Haddington andpeople come to visit the town I take them down to the bridge.ldquoIt is my favourite spot in Haddington ndash outside the Waterside and sitting there.ldquoI didnrsquot know it was going to be so popular!Paul Darling, Neil Walker, Julie Cove and Kathryn Winn were named as runners-up and have also had their pictures made into jigsaws, which are available from the lending library.Pat Lemmon, who has been heavily involved in the community resilience efforts, said the competition had been a great success.She said: ldquoWe have got about  followers on Facebook and we have just under  people signed up to us for the service.ldquoAt the moment, around  items are out on loan.The library is well stocked, with just under  books, about  jigsaws ndash including the five selected through the competition ndash about  games and ldquohundreds of DVDs.Mrs Lemmon, who is also on the townrsquos community council, said the donated items went through a sanitising process.Similarly, the items are delivered by members of the resilience team wearing gloves and can be placed on the personrsquos doorstep.The jigsaws have proved very popular and Mrs Lemmon said: ldquoI think it is a way to release boredom and keep minds active.ldquoIt passes the time and gives people something to do other than watching television.ldquoWhen you cannot sit out in the garden, you can work away at the jigsaw.ldquoFor people without gardens ndash and there are many ndash it is something to keep them occupied.Anyone looking to borrow something from the lending library can search for Haddington Lending Library on Facebook or call the Haddington resilience phone number on  .

title: search-way-find-new-council-head-education
story: Fiona Robertson left her role as head of education and childrenrsquos services at East Lothian Council towards the end of last year to take up a new post with neighbouring Midlothian Council.The job of overseeing education services during the coronavirus crisis has been carried out byLesley Brown, the local authorityrsquos chief operating officer for education.Advertising the post of head of education and childrenrsquos services, the council said: ldquoIn a period of signicant change, development and local population growth, we are ambitious for the future of our special county and the residents we serve.ldquoDelivering the more prosperous, safe and sustainable East Lothian we all want to see includes helping our children achieve their fullest potential in le.ldquoWe want to ensure they benefit from the best start in le, to enjoy being young, and to grow and develop in a safe, supportive environment.ldquoOur head of education and childrenrsquos services will play a vital leadership role in developing the services and partnerships that will enable children and young people to live safe, healthier, more active and independent lives.Monica Patterson, chief executive of the council, said the new appointment would play a vital leadership role in developing the services and partnerships that would enable children and young people to live safe, healthier, more active and independent lives.

title: plans-way-return-haddington-farmers-market
story: Haddington Farmersrsquo Market, like many groups across the country, was forced to cancel a number of events due to the coronavirus pandemic.However, with restrictions easing, organisers have a view to holding a market on July .Val Shields, chairwoman of the farmersrsquo market, was pleased to say the market looked set tobut stressed that measures would still be taken to maintain public safety.One-way systems, social distancing, hand-sanitising stations and stewards would be just some of the measures taken to ensure the event could go ahead in a safe manner.The market takes place on the last Saturday of each month on Haddingtonrsquos Court Street from am to pm.However, the event has not taken place since February due to the global pandemic.

title: msp-urges-support-festivals-ensure-return
story: The county plays host to a wide iety of events, with many having been postponed due to the Covid- pandemic and others, which are scheduled to take place later this year, still weighing up their options.Fringe by the Sea was due to take place next month in North Berwick but was postponed until next year, while the organisers of the Lammermuir Festival, which is due to take place from September  to , have said they are ldquomonitoring developments and Government guidelines closely.At last weekrsquos culture questions in the Scottish Parliament, East Lothian MSP Iain Gray asked the Scottish Government how it planned to give the sector help to ensure festivals couldin .Mr Gray used his supplementary question to stress the need for state support, including funding for local festivals to help them recover from the pandemic and lockdown.He described the county as having ldquoa thriving arts and culture scene and said: ldquoMusic is an important part of that scene and includes several successful local festivals.ldquoAs well as providing important opportunities for local people to access the arts, these events also help boost tourism by bringing visitors to the county.ldquoHowever, like so many areas of le, cultural events, including music festivals, have been hit hard by the pandemic, with many cancelled or postponed over recent months.ldquoAs we begin the recovery from the impact of the virus, I am keen to ensure that our music festivals receive state support to help them.Fiona Hyslop MSP, cabinet secretary for economy, fair work and culture, echoed the importance of the culture sector.Resilience and creative hardship funds have been set up and Ms Hyslop stressed it was key that the sector ldquorebound strongly from the crisis.She said: ldquoCreative Scotland has ensured that regularly funded organisations ndash many of which are involved in small local festivals ndash have had their funding extended for  to allow them toin .ldquoIt is also encouraging local festivals to honour contracted payments to freelance performers who were booked for . Some are negotiating part payment now and part payment for .ldquoHowever, as Iain Gray pointed out, not all festivals will be funded by Creative Scotland therefore, we have to look at things in the round.

title: walk-scott-foundation-boosts-waggonway-project
story: The project saw its crowdfunding campaign raise pound in just  hours as supporters backed its appeal for help.And the foundation offered to match the amount raised in tribute to its founder Scott Glynn, who was a keen supporter of the Waggonway.Karen Kidd, from the foundation, said: ldquoScott loved the Waggonway Project and wersquore delighted to be able to help with this funding.Ed Bethune, from the  Waggonway Heritage Group, said the project was facing challenges like so many other heritage organisations, as it moved into a third month of its museum ndash which is based on West Harbour Road, Cockenzie ndash remaining closed because of lockdown.The funds raised by the crowdfunding effort and from the foundation will help support the project during the tough current climate and into the future.Ed said: ldquoWersquore hugely grateful to the Walk With Scott Foundation for this incredible gesture at this time, which will help us bring the Waggonway Project through the current challenges and come out stronger on the other side.ldquoOur thanks go to all those who have donated, itrsquos a real example of the passion for local heritage and wersquore incredibly grateful for the support.The group is still fundraising via the JustGiving page and anyone wishing to donate can do so via justgiving crowdfunding waggonway

title: volunteers-cook-10-000th-meal-help-need-lockdown
story: Farsquoside Emergency Food Provision, which is based at St Martinrsquos Church Hall, has been serving up meals to hundreds of households in the Farsquoside area since the pandemic started.Last Wednesday, volunteers Duncan McBride and Joyce and Andy Thomson dished up their ,th meal at the townrsquos East Lothian Co-operative Bowling Club, where they have been cooking five days a week and playing a central role in ensuring residents who have been shielding receive a hot meal.The trio of volunteers got involved after a call from Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council for local people to volunteer their skills and experience.The need for hot meals to be prepared and delivered was identied and Duncan got his long-time friends Andy and Joyce Thomson involved, with Joyce, who works at the club, approaching bowling club secretary Greg McGinn about using the premises.Greg said: ldquoAs a club we are very much involved in the community and we were only happy to help. Thanks to the resilience team, community council and everyone who donated supplies and donations. However, the real heroes are Duncan, Joyce and Andy.What started out as a request to batch cook food, especially for the older residents a couple of days per week, turned into a full-time job for all three volunteers, who produced about  meals a day.They have each clocked up  volunteer hours since they started.Ruth Davie, from Fundamental Foods, which set up the emergency food provision, said: ldquoWe are grateful for the support of the Store Club and their premises and we cannot thank our dream batch cooking trio enough for all their hard work, especially their passion to make us delicious hot meals for those who need it most ndash it has brightened up a very dficult time for many local residents who have been receiving daily food parcels.ldquoFeedback from one elderly recipient said: lsquoSomeone cares about me and this is the highlight of my day when the lovely man drops off my food parcel.rsquoldquoWith support from Farsquoside Area Partnership, who provided Fundamental Foods with the start-up money to get the provision up and running, along with ongoing support through East Lothian Council and a range of partners, including regular and much-appreciated kind donations from local residents, we have managed to keep the hot meal element of the provision.ldquoNone of this would have been possible without the time, effort, commitment, and passion that Duncan, Andy and Joyce have shown.The team extended its provision to Blair Hall to increase capacity to meet demand and thanked St Martinrsquos Parish and Blair Hall LOL for their support.

title: aldis-move-new-haddington-retail-park-receives-boost
story: Supermarket giant Aldi was given planning permission for a new store at Gateside Retail Park, on the townrsquos western edge, last year.Now, advertising consent, which will allow ious signs to be put in place, has also been granted by East Lothian Council.The supermarket chain is yet to reveal any opening date for the store, which will be  per cent larger than its existing premises in town.However, the opening will also signal the end of the Whittingehame Drive store, with Aldi closing its doors after more than a decade in the town centre.The current  members of staff at the existing store will be offered the chance to move to the new premises, which will be joined by The Food Warehouse, part of the Iceland brand.Home Bargains and Costa are also thought to be keen to move to the retail park, which is sandwiched between the A and B.The retail park includes three major stores, two restaurants, including one drive-thru, and about  parking spaces.Planning permission has also been given to neighbouring sites for a petrol station and shop and a drive-thru coffee shop, thought to be a Starbucks.Earlier this year, Aldi confirmed a purchaser for the Whittingehame Drive site had been identied but the intended use was unknown.No objections were received from members of the public regarding the latest plans to erect signs.

title: letter-week-need-look-coast
story: The coastline and woodland here are of high conservation value and when the council introduced the coastal car parking policy, they deliberately restricted the spaces here to limit disturbance of the important sensitive habitats and wildle.They could have decided to create a larger car parking area to maximise income but, to their credit, they did not do this.In contrast, they allowed much more parking on the opposite side of the estuary, at John Muir Country Park, which is closer to Dunbar and the East Links Family Park.Such zoning is a useful tool both to provide space for people to freely enjoy the outdoors while also protectinghabitats for wildle and for those who prefer a more peaceful environment.Although I support the actions of the council for the reasons given, I do think they should have gone further and imposed some additional restrictions within the John Muir Country Park on the east side of the estuary.In particular, dogs off the lead persistently disturb feeding and nesting birds and I believe that dogs should only be allowed in the area of the country park west of the car park and toilet blockthey are on a lead.At present the only coastal area on the East Lothian coast where there are restrictions on dogs is the Aberlady Bay nature reserve .We owe it to our citizens and visitors, both now and in the future, to preserve what natural heritage we still have along our coasts.Mark HollingNorth Berwick

title: school-improvement-works-take-place-summer-holidays
story: Various works are planned for Macmerry Primary School, which, like all schools across East Lothian, has been shut for several weeks due to the coronavirus.East Lothian Council gave plans to upgrade the roof the green light last month, with the intention for work to be carried out during the school summer holidays to minimise disruption for the children.A letter outlining the works has been sent out to the school community by Jonathan Revell, the schoolrsquos headteacher.It notes: ldquoWork has already begun to repair external stonework on our nursery building and you may have already seen vans and scaffolding in place.ldquoAs you know, the council has been monitoring the condition of our gym hall roof and carrying out extensive surveys.ldquoBased on advice from a structural engineer, the decision has been taken to remove the gym hall roof and replace it.ldquoAs this roof contains asbestos, its removal will be carried out by specialist contractors under licence and in line with all regulations.ldquoA new wall has already been built between our main hall and the gym hall, completely sealing off the space from the rest of the school.ldquoA specialist deep clean will be carried out once work is completed.ldquoThe timetable has been planned to complete the roof removal before the end of the summer holidays.ldquoHowever, the impacts of Covid- on the construction industry throughout lockdown, and theto school on August , which is earlier than our original term dates, means there is a possibility that the timetable could overrun.ldquoI am working with education and engineering colleagues to develop a contingency plan that would minimise disruption and remove risk.ldquoI want to make you aware of this possibility but also to reassure you that every effort will be made to complete this part of the project within the summer holiday period.ldquoOnce the roof has been removed, a second phase of work will begin to replace it.ldquoWe expect that this will be completed by the end of October.ldquoConstruction work will be carried out to minimise disruption to our learning activities and in line with all of the necessary hygiene and physical distancing requirements.A letter will also be sent out to parents and carers next month to give an update on the progress of the scheme.No objections were made to the proposals, which were put forward by East Lothian Council.According to the planning officerrsquos report: ldquoThe works proposed are to upgrade, maintain and improve the overall quality and appearance of the building.

title: two-new-homes-planned-back-garden-town-centre-house
story: James Scally is looking to see the properties built to the rear of  Bridge Street.The three-storey building would see a garage on the ground floor, with the living accommodation above.Drawings included within the planning application, which has been lodged with East Lothian Council, show a kitchen, living room and dining area on the first floor, while two bedrooms would be situated on the second floor.

title: new-plans-revealed-former-dunbar-coastguard-station
story: The small building on Dunbarrsquos Lamer Street has sat empty since the townrsquos coastguard team moved to Spott Road Industrial Estate more than six months ago.In April, East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department turned down Judy Oxleyrsquos bid to turn the building into a beachfront home.At that time, planners took the view that the constrained nature of the building would allow neither privacy nor amenity for occupants.Ms Oxley has lodged an appeal against that decision and has also submitted further plans to see the building transformed into holiday accommodation.A supporting statement, included with the latest planning application, notes discussions have already taken place between the applicant and planners, with ldquopositive feedback.Drawings show the building would see a bedroom, dining room and wet room created downstairs, with a living room, storage space and balcony above.

title: coronavirus-impacts-upon-pure-malts-upgrade-plans
story: Pure Malt Products has been given the go-ahead to make changes to the five-storey Bermaline Maltings building, off the townrsquos Whittingehame Drive.The building is listed as being of special architectural or historic interest and the business, which is a global leader in manufacturing malt-based ingredients for a wide iety of products, had impressive plans for the site.However, those moves could be halted by the coronavirus outbreak, despite East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department having already given the scheme the green light.According to the planning officerrsquos report: ldquoThe building has been signicantly altered throughout its history, with replacement floors and many structural interventions to accommodate the changing uses and processes within it.ldquoThe building is currently only partly used by Pure Malt, who are continuing the nearly  yearsrsquo use of the site in the processing of grains and cereals.ldquoThe remainder of the building is currently unused and has fallen into disrepair.ldquoEssential maintenance works are now required to prevent the building falling into a dangerous state.The planned alterations to the building are to facilitate the upgrading of the existing facilities on the site.Much of the external work includes the installation of roof lights, with two new sections of roof and the re-opening of former windows.Inside, documents show changes planned on ious floors.On the ground floor, three unused malting rooms would be transformed, with a -seat canteen being created, as well as a reception area and changing facilities for men and women.There are also plans for a staff gym on the ground floor.Upstairs on the first floor would be office space, including meeting rooms, with further meeting rooms created on the second floor, as well as other rooms, including a micro lab.Currently, the business has premises on both sides of Whittingehame Drive.No objections were received by East Lothian Council regarding the plans, although no start date has been identied for the work to get under way.

title: st-gabriels-rc-primary-schools-headteacher-deputy-retire
story: Anne Torley, who has been headteacher at St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School since , departed along with deputy Sue Adams, who had been at the school for  years.The double retirement was a fitting one for both women, as they first met at teacher training college in Edinburgh in the early s.Mrs Torley described Mrs Adams as her ldquoother half as she revealed they reconnected when she took the helm at St Gabrielrsquos ndash  years after they left St Andrewrsquos College of Education in Edinburgh ndash and became a close team.Praising Mrs Adams, Mrs Torley said: ldquoWe have had such fun pulling together an outstanding team.The retiring headteacher, who came to St Gabrielrsquos after nearly five years as headteacher of Ormiston Primary School, said she was leaving with many happy memories.And she urged pupils to keep up their positive attitudes during the coronavirus crisis, which meant she and Mrs Adams were unable to say goodbye in person.She said: ldquoIt is unfortunate but unavoidable that we cannot say a personal thank you andcongratulationsto all of our pupils at StGabrielrsquos ndash but we will not forget you.ldquoI would ask all of the children of StGabrielrsquos to keep up that positive attitude. I know you will do great things in the future.ldquoTake pride in how far you have come and have faith in how far you can go. Believe in yourselves and rememberhellip you can!Mrs Torley described leaving St Gabrielrsquos as a ldquobitter sweet time as she retires after  years as a teacher but said she was looking forward to new adventures.She said: ldquoStGabrielrsquos is very close to my heart but I am now looking forward to spending more time relaxing with my own family and learning new skills and having new adventures.She thanked the school community, saying: ldquoI am so very proud of the amazing and close-knit team we have become. Thank you also to the parents for their immense support over the years and to the local authority for making East Lothian such an attractive and worthwhile place to work.ldquoIt has been a privilege to work here, a fantastic journey, and I will hold many fond and special memories of you all.Mrs Adams also spoke of her pride in working at the school her daughters Rhianna and Josie attended.She said: ldquoStGabrielrsquos to me is part of my family. I joined the staff in  so Irsquove spent most of my adult le here. My daughters were pupils here ndash in fact, I taught them both.ldquoTherersquos something special about this school it pulls in special people, supportive parents and our staff teams have always had a close bond.ldquoAfter nearly  years Irsquove got to know a lot of pupils and itrsquos the big and small moments with the pupils that make you think, lsquoI am so lucky, I have had the best job in the worldrsquo.Eileen Rafferty, religious education advisor for the Archdiocese of St Andrewrsquos and Edinburgh, paid tribute to the retiring teachers.She said: ldquoSue and Anne always have childrenrsquos best interests at heart and have fostered a welcoming and inclusive school environment at St Gabrielrsquos.ldquoTheyrsquove done a sterling job and everyone in the Archdiocese wishes them a happy retirement.Margaret McBean, headteacher at Loretto RC Primary School in Musselburgh, will serve as acting headteacher until a permanent replacement for Mrs Torley is found.

story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at www.tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk or by going to www.eastlinton.ukPeople can also call   or  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickEAST Dirleton, Gullane, Ballencrieff, Drem, Fenton Barns and Kingston.North Berwick Coastal ward councillors Jeremy Findlay, Jim Goodfellow and Jane Henderson, as well as Dunbar and East Linton councillor Paul McLennan and Provost John McMillan, are involved in a Zoom meeting hosted by North Berwick Community Council, on Wednesday at pm.North Berwick Community Council chairwoman Judy Lockhart said the councillors wanted to hear what problems businesses might be facing and how they could be best supported.She said: ldquoIf you want to take this opportunity to talk to them directly, please get in touch via email so we can send you the meeting link.ldquoJust email nbc-ap@eastlothian.gov.uk and mark your message lsquoRecovery and Renewalrsquo.Meanwhile, the games swap shop at North Berwick story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Aberlady. Government guidance to avoid a spike in the virus, as more areas of leto normal in the days ahead.He said: ldquoThere have been a lot of positive announcements in the past  days by both the UK and Scottish Governments in relation to the economy opening up, with the number of virus cases and deaths falling signicantly in Scotland.ldquoThis week, non-food retail shops opened and dates have been ldquoWersquove had people saying itrsquos been a lsquolelinersquo, that they donrsquot know what they would have done without the provision and people just stressing how much they needed the story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.HaddingtonHaddingtonRESILIENCE volunteers in Haddington have stressed they will continue to be there for people in need, despite restrictions being eased.Kind-hearted volunteers throughout the town have been busy for the last three months offering support to vulnerable members of the community.Lockdown restrictions continue to be relaxed but Chris McEwan, who has been heavily involved in the community resilience efforts, stressed the volunteers would continue to be on hand to help.However, he said: ldquoThings have been starting to really quieten down, with a lot of people going out and about.The volunteers have offered a range of services, including collecting prescriptions and shopping, as well as walking dogs.Chris said those services would continue to be available to those who needed them, particularly with many people going back to work.He added: ldquoWe are expecting a bit of a surge from people who did get help from their neighbours.ldquoNow, they have nobody to help them, even with shielding.Contact detailsAnyone looking for assistance should phone   between am and pm.East Saltoun. Picture: Google MapsHumbie, East and West Saltoun, and BoltonCOMMUNITY efforts have helped bring East Saltoun closer together, according to a lead volunteer.Coronavirus and lockdown restrictions have meant vulnerable people relying on the kind-hearted nature of neighbours and other people across the county.Buffy Neilson, the single point of contact in East Saltoun, was pleased to say they continued to cope with demand.She said: ldquoWe are still managing to get volunteers, despite the fact folk have busy lives and are back at work.ldquoIt is just business as usual.ldquoWe are getting slightly fewer requests but nonetheless we are getting lots and lots of pharmacy visits and shopping we are still coping.ldquoPeople have busy lives and people are beginning to go back to work but we are still managing.ldquoWe have enough volunteers and a really good pool of folk who are willing to help out.ldquoIt is wonderful it has brought the village community together.Contact detailsFor those needing assistance, people in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by emailing shenajamieson@aolEast Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahooIn West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmailIn Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailMusselburgh. We also provided activities to five children, including sun catchers to paint, to meet some needs during adult week.ldquoWe have continued to receive the support of many community groups and a big thank you goes to the Musselburgh First Step Community Project for their recent financial donation.Resilient Musselburgh is being led by Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council and the area partnership.Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .Tranent. Picture: Google MapsTranent and ElphinstoneTHE resilience group in Tranent and Elphinstone marked the efforts of two of its volunteers for the huge milestone they reached this week.Joyce Thomson and Duncan McBride have prepared , meals for people in the Farsquoside area since the start of lockdown.The pair have been based in the East Lothian Co-operative Bowling Club, on Tranentrsquos Blawearie Road.They would be in the bowling club five or six days a week making meals for those in need in the area.Two industrial-sized fridgefreezers were also delivered to the club to store food and meals.Ingredients have been provided by either the Pennypit Trust or donations from the local community.The meals were delivered by about  volunteer delivery drivers, six of whom have volunteered since the start of lockdown.On Tuesday, a small celebratory ceremony with cake was held for the pair, attended by representatives from the bowling club, as well as Simon Davie, area manager for Farsquoside Area Partnership.The resilience efforts in Tranent and Elphinstone are led by the local community council, overseen by its single point of contactMike Falconer.Mike commended the pairrsquos achievement and said Joyce and Duncan had done ldquoa great job. title: air-bridges-apply-scotland-can-go-holiday-abroad
story: The current -day isolation policy for peopleto or visiting Scotland remains in place for now, the Scottish Government has confirmed, despite the restrictions being eased south of the Border.As it stands, people from England will be able to travel to destinations such as Spain, France, Italy and Germany.A full list of countries which the UK Government says pose a ldquoreduced risk of Covid- will be published later today, and could feature as many as  nations.However, it is not guaranteed that travellers from the UK would not have to self-isolate on arrival into some of the other states.The blanket guide against all but essential travel will also be changed tomorrow.What is an air bridge An air bridge, also known as a travel corridor, will allow tourists to travel between two countries without the need to quarantine.The agreements between countries, particularly those with low cases ofcoronavirus, allow two-way travel without restrictions.Do air bridges apply to Scotland The First Minister has criticised the UK Government for failing to consult the devolved administration before announcing the proposed changes.The Scottish Government says a four-nations agreement had chosen to make an announcement on the countries they intend to exempt before a four nations agreement has been reached, he said.ldquoWe would still like to reach a four nations approachpossible, but that is dficult when the UK Government change proposals and give us last-minute sight of them.While border controls remains a reserved matter, the issue of health is devolved ndash therefore allowing title: unexploded-device-found-east-lothian-coastline
story: North Berwickrsquos Coastguard Rescue Team was called out at pm on Wednesday after the item, believed to be unexploded ordnance, was found on sand dunes between North Berwick Golf Clubs West Links and Yellowcraig.On scene, members met with the person that found the device and took photographs of the item, which will be passed on to the Royal Naval Explosion Ordnance Division .It is not knownthe device was explosive but it was treated asit was according to the Coastguard.A spokesman for the Coastguard said: ldquoDue to the location of the item Police Scotland attended to secure the area until a full assessment could be made.ldquoThe team stood down awaiting update from EOD   Police.ldquoIf you find an item you believe may be old military explosives, shells, mines etc on the coast, call  and ask for the Coastguard.ldquoRememberyou see someone or something you are concerned about on the shoreline, clf, mud or on the sea."Dial  and ask for the Coastguard. If in doubt, callldquoThere is an alternative contact number for the Coastguard,   where you can pass information.A spokeswoman for Police Scotland confirmed they had been called out to the site and were there beyond midnight.She added: "Officers attended and EOD were contacted."EOD staff attended and carried out a controlled explosion."

title: council-plans-20mph-speed-limit-towns
